perturbation.original_text: 4.2.2 Without limitation, Otis and Carrier as promptly as reasonably practicable (but in any case within six (6) months of the Effective Time) shall cause each member of, respectively, the Otis Group and the Carrier Group having a corporate name that includes any of the United Technologies Trademarks to apply to change its corporate name to a name that does not include any of the United Technologies Trademarks, including, within six (6) months of the Effective Time, by making any legal filings in each relevant jurisdiction necessary to effect such change worldwide.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.2.2 Without limitation, Otis and Carrier shall cause each member of, respectively, the Otis Group and the Carrier Group having a corporate name that includes any of the United Technologies Trademarks to apply to change its corporate name to a name that does not include any of the United Technologies Trademarks within eighteen (18) months of the Effective Time. Legal filings in each relevant jurisdiction necessary to effect such change worldwide must be completed within twenty-four (24) months of the Effective Time.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires the companies to change their corporate names and complete legal filings within six months. The modified text extends these deadlines to 18 and 24 months, respectively. While seemingly innocuous, this could conflict with state-level requirements for updating corporate registration details or trademark usage rights post-separation. For example, some states mandate updates to reflect the new corporate structure and prevent confusion within a shorter timeframe than the extended periods provided here. Therefore, this adjustment introduces a legal contradiction if the jurisdiction requires compliance within a shorter timeframe.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Corporate Registration Laws, Trademark Laws

perturbation.original_text: 7.1.1 For a period of six (6) months after the Effective Time, upon written request by an Assignee Party or a Licensee Party, and solely to the extent the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group or the Licensor Party or another member of the Licensor Group, respectively, has the right to do so, the Assignor Party or the Licensor Party, respectively, shall use commercially reasonable efforts to provide (and to cause other members of the Assignor Group or the Licensor Group, respectively, to provide) to the requesting Assignee Party or the Licensee Party, respectively, copies of tangible embodiments of the Assigned Intellectual Property Rights and the Licensed Intellectual Property Rights, respectively, in the possession of a member of the Assignor Group or the Licensor Group, respectively, and not in the possession of a member of the Assignee Group or the Licensee Group, respectively, upon the Effective Time, to the extent that both (a) such Assigned Intellectual Property Rights or such Licensed Intellectual Property Rights, respectively, are necessary for the ongoing conduct of the current 13 business of the requesting Assignee Party or another member of the Assignee Group or the requesting Licensee Party or another member of the Licensee Group, respectively, or was in use in such business as of the Effective Time, and (b) such tangible embodiments are reasonably necessary for the use of such Assigned Intellectual Property Rights or such Licensed Intellectual Property Rights, respectively, identified in Section 7.1.1(a).
perturbation.changed_text: 7.1.1 For a period of thirty (30) days after the Effective Time, upon written request by an Assignee Party or a Licensee Party, the Assignor Party or the Licensor Party, respectively, shall use commercially reasonable efforts to provide copies of tangible embodiments of the Assigned Intellectual Property Rights and the Licensed Intellectual Property Rights.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a six-month window for requesting copies of tangible embodiments of intellectual property. The modified text reduces this window to 30 days. This could conflict with laws related to transition periods post-separation or acquisition, where longer periods are legally mandated to ensure a smooth transfer of assets and knowledge. Shortening the period to 30 days creates a potential legal contradiction if relevant regulations require a more extended period for the transfer of necessary IP.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Laws regarding transition periods in corporate separations/acquisitions

perturbation.original_text: 9.5 Notice. All notices or other communications required or permitted hereunder by a Party shall be in writing to the other Parties at the address provided below (or at such other address as such Party may designate by notice pursuant to this Section 9.5), and shall be deemed given or delivered (a) when delivered personally against written receipt, (b) if sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, when received, and (c) when delivered by a nationally recognized overnight courier service, prepaid:
perturbation.changed_text: 9.5 Notice. All notices or other communications required or permitted hereunder by a Party shall be in writing to the other Parties at the address provided below (or at such other address as such Party may designate by notice pursuant to this Section 9.5), and shall be deemed given or delivered only when sent via electronic mail.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows for multiple methods of delivering notices, including personal delivery, registered/certified mail, and overnight courier. The modified text restricts notice delivery to electronic mail only. This contradicts standard legal practices and potentially conflicts with requirements in certain jurisdictions that legally require certain types of notices (e.g., notices of default, termination) to be delivered via certified mail or similar methods to ensure proof of receipt.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law regarding proper notification; State laws requiring certain notifications via certified mail
